In the past, Emperor Ming of the Han Dynasty had a dream at night of a divine person with a golden-colored body,
with a sun-like light on his neck, flying in front of the palace. He was delighted and very pleased.
The next day, he asked the officials:
What kind of spirit is this?
The knowledgeable Fu Yi said:
Your subject has heard that in India there is one who has attained the Way, called the Buddha, who can fly with lightness. It is probably his spirit.

Thereupon, the Emperor realized and immediately sent envoys Zhang Qian, the General of the Imperial Bodyguard Qin Jing, and Wang Zun, a student of the Imperial University, and twelve others, to the country of the Great Yuezhi, where they copied the Buddhist scriptures in forty-two sections.
They placed them in a stone casket in the fourteenth level and erected pagodas and temples. Thus, the Way and the Dharma spread, and Buddhist temples were established everywhere.

The number of distant people who submitted to his transformation and wished to become his ministers and concubines was innumerable. The country was peaceful and secure, and all sentient beings benefited from his grace and received his support, which continues to this day without interruption.
The Buddha said:

Leaving one's parents to go forth and practice the Way is called 'Å›ramaá¹‡a'. Always practicing the two hundred and fifty precepts is the four true paths of practice. Advancing with a pure mind, one becomes an arhat.
An arhat can fly, transform, and live for a long time, shaking the heavens and the earth;
Next is the anÄgÄmin. An anÄgÄmin, at the end of their life, their spirit ascends to the nineteenth heaven, where they attain arhatship;
Next is the saká¹›dÄgÄmin. A saká¹›dÄgÄmin, after one more birth, attains arhatship;
Next is the srota-Äpanna. A srota-Äpanna, after seven deaths and seven births, attains arhatship;
Cutting off desire is like cutting off four limbs, which are no longer used.
The Buddha said:
Shaving the beard and hair, becoming a monk, receiving the Way, abandoning worldly wealth, begging for sustenance, eating once a day, sleeping under a tree, and not doing it again.
What makes people foolish and stubborn is love and desire.
The Buddha said:
Sentient beings do good through ten things, and also do evil through ten things.
Body three, mouth four, mind three.
The three of the body are:
Killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct;
The four of the mouth are:
Slander, harsh speech, false speech, and frivolous speech;
The three of the mind are:
Jealousy, anger, and delusion, not believing in the Three Jewels, taking falsehood as true.
UpÄsakas who practice five things without slacking off, and ten things, will surely attain the Way.
The Buddha said:
People have many faults, but do not repent themselves, and stop their minds abruptly. Sins come back to the body, just as water returns to the sea, and naturally become deep and vast.
If one recognizes their faults and corrects them, one can attain goodness, and their sins will gradually be eliminated, and they will eventually attain the Way.
The Buddha said:
I consider people's foolishness to be unwholesome, so I protect them with the four kinds of kindness and compassion.
If they continue to come with evil, I will go to them with even more goodness, and the energy of blessings and virtues will always be here;
The energy of harm and heavy misfortune will return to them.
Someone heard that the Buddha's Way upholds great kindness and compassion, so they came to scold him, bringing evil and going with goodness.
The Buddha remained silent and did not respond, feeling pity for their foolishness and delusion.
When the scolding stopped, he asked:
If you offer a gift to someone, and they do not accept it, what do you do with the gift?
He said:
I take it back.
Now you scold me, and I also do not accept it. You take it back yourself, and the misfortune will befall you.
It is like an echo responding to a sound, or a shadow following a form, there is no escape from it. Be careful not to do evil.
The Buddha said:
Evil people harming the virtuous are like looking up at the sky and spitting. The spit does not defile the sky but defiles oneself;
Going against the wind to dust a person, the dust does not defile them but rather dusts oneself.
The virtuous cannot be defiled, and the calamity will surely destroy oneself.
The Buddha said:
When people practice the Way, they should be magnanimous in love. Generosity in compassion and virtue is the greatest giving.
Upholding the will and following the Way, its blessings are very great;
Seeing others give and practice the Way, assisting them with joy, one will also obtain blessed rewards.
Zhi said:
Should those blessings not be diminished?
The Buddha said:
It is like a torch. Countless thousands and hundreds of people each come with torches, take the fire away to cook food and dispel darkness;
That fire remains as it was, and blessings are also like this.
The Buddha said:

Feeding a hundred ordinary people is not as good as feeding a single virtuous person; feeding a thousand virtuous people is not as good as feeding a single person who upholds the five precepts; feeding ten thousand people who uphold the five precepts is not as good as feeding a single stream-enterer; feeding a hundred thousand stream-enterers is not as good as feeding a single once-returner; feeding a thousand once-returners is not as good as feeding a single non-returner; feeding ten million non-returners is not as good as feeding a single arhat; feeding a hundred million arhats is not as good as feeding a single pratyekabuddha; feeding a billion pratyekabuddhas is not as good as using the teachings of the Three Jewels to deliver one's parents for a lifetime. Teaching one's parents is a thousand billion times better than feeding a single buddha - studying and vowing to seek buddhahood in order to deliver sentient beings.

The merit of feeding virtuous people is the deepest and most profound. Ordinary people serve Heaven, Earth, and spirits, but nothing compares to being filial to one's parents, for one's parents are the most spiritual.
The Buddha said:
There are five difficulties in the world:

It is difficult for the poor to give, difficult for the wealthy to study the Way, difficult to control one's life and not die, difficult to see the Buddha's scriptures, and difficult to be born in the Buddha's time.
A Å›ramaá¹‡a asked the Buddha:
By what means can one attain the Way?
How can one know one's past lives?
The Buddha said:
The Way has no form. Knowing it is of no benefit. One must guard one's will and practice;

It is like polishing a mirror. When the dust is gone and the brightness remains, one can see one's own form. Cutting off desires and guarding emptiness is seeing the true Way and knowing one's past lives.
The Buddha said:
What is good?
Only practicing the Way is good.
What is greatest?
The will in accord with the Way is great.
What has the most power?
Forbearance is the strongest. The forbearing have no resentment and will surely be revered by others.
What is most illuminating?
The mind's defilements are removed and evil deeds cease. Internally pure and flawless;

From before the existence of heaven and earth up to today, all that exists in the ten directions, the sprouts that have not yet been seen, there is nothing that is not known, nothing that is not seen, nothing that is not heard. Having attained omniscience, one can be said to be enlightened.
The Buddha said:

A person who harbors desires does not see the Way, just as turbid water, into which five colors are thrown, is stirred vigorously, and many people look at the water's surface, none of them can see their reflections;
Desires intertwining, the mind becomes turbid, and thus one does not see the Way;
When the water is clear and the impurities removed, pure and spotless, one then sees one's own form.
A fierce fire is placed under a cauldron, and the water inside boils up, covered with a cloth on top, and living beings look at it, also not seeing their reflections;
In the mind, there are originally the three poisons boiling inside, and the five hindrances cover the outside, and one never sees the Way;
Only when the mind's defilements are exhausted will one know where the soul and spirit come from, where life and death lead, and where the Buddha lands and the Way are.
The Buddha said:

Those who practice the Way are like holding a torch and entering a dark room. The darkness immediately disappears, and the light remains. When practicing the Way and seeing the truth, ignorance completely disappears, and one attains the state of non-seeing.
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½What do I think of the Way?
What do I practice in practicing the Way?
What do I speak of when speaking of the Way?
I think of the true Way, not missing a moment.
The Buddha said:
Seeing heaven and earth, think of impermanence. Seeing mountains and rivers, think of impermanence. Seeing the abundant forms and bodies of myriad things, think of impermanence;
Grasping the mind like this, one quickly attains the Way.
The Buddha said:
Walking one day, always thinking of the Way and practicing the Way, one eventually attains the root of faith, and the blessings are immeasurable.
The Buddha said:

Contemplate the four great elements within your body, which are named and yet ultimately non-existent. The self is a guest, and even when born, it does not last long. Its affairs are like an illusion.
The Buddha said:
People pursue fame and wealth according to their desires, like burning incense. While many people smell its fragrance, the incense itself is consumed by the burning.
The foolish crave the fame and praise of the world, not guarding the truth of the Way. The danger of fame and wealth brings harm to oneself, and one will regret it later.
The Buddha said:
Wealth and beauty to people are like a child greedy for the honey on a knife's edge. The sweetness is not worth a single meal's delight, but there is the danger of cutting off one's tongue.
The Buddha said:
The danger of being bound to one's wife, children, and precious home is worse than prison, shackles, and chains.
Prisons have pardons, but the desire for wife and children, even with the danger of being thrown to tigers, people still willingly submit to it. Their crimes have no pardon.
The Buddha said:
There is no desire greater than that for form, and the desire for form is vast, with nothing outside it.
If there were a second, even with the first, there would be no one in the world who could practice the Way.
The Buddha said:
Desire for a person is like holding a torch against the wind while walking.
A fool does not let go of the torch, and will surely burn his hand.

The poisons of greed, anger, and delusion are present in the human body. If one does not quickly eliminate these calamities with the Way, there will surely be danger and misfortune, just like the fool who greedily holds the torch and burns his own hand.
A celestial spirit offered a jade maiden to the Buddha, wanting to test the Buddha's mind and observe the Buddha's Way.
The Buddha said:
A leather bag full of impurities, what are you coming for?
This is acceptable to the vulgar, but it is difficult to move the six supernatural powers.
Go away!
I do not need you.
The celestial spirit surpassed in respect for the Buddha and then asked about the meaning of the Way;
The Buddha explained it for him, and he immediately attained the stage of stream-entry.
The Buddha said:
Those who practice the Way are like wood floating on water, following the current, not touching the left bank, nor the right bank;
not being taken by people, not being obstructed by ghosts and spirits, not being stopped by whirlpools, and not rotting, I guarantee that it will enter the ocean.
People practicing the Way, not being confused by desires, not being deceived by various evils, diligently practicing without doubt, I guarantee that they will attain the Way.
The Buddha told the monks:
Be careful not to trust your mind, for the mind can never be trusted.
Be careful not to have sexual relations, for having sexual relations will bring disaster.
Only after attaining the state of an arhat can you trust your mind.
The Buddha told the monks:
Be careful not to look at women, if you see them, do not look.
Be careful not to speak with them, if you do speak with them, admonish your mind to be upright and say:
I am a Å›ramaá¹‡a, dwelling in a turbid world, I should be like a lotus flower, not defiled by the mud.
The elderly are considered mothers, the seniors are considered sisters, the young are considered daughters, and the young are considered sons, respecting them with propriety.

The mind should be deeply contemplated, from head to toe, observing within oneself, what does this body have? It is only filled with foul-smelling impurities and various impure substances, thus releasing the mind.
The Buddha said:
People who pursue the Way to remove desires, should be like grass seeing fire, retreating as the fire approaches.
Practitioners of the Way, upon seeing desires, must distance themselves from them.
The Buddha said:
People who suffer from lust, whose desires are unceasing, sit on the edge of an ax, using it to cut off their genitals.
The Buddha told him:
If you cut off the genitals, it is not as good as cutting off the mind. The mind is the leader. If you stop the leader, the followers all cease.
If the deviant mind does not stop, what benefit is there in cutting off the genitals?
In an instant, you will die.
The Buddha said:
The inverted views of worldly people are like this kind of foolish person.
There was a lustful young woman who made a promise with a man, but when the time came, he did not come. She then regretted and said:
I know your origin, desire, you are born from thoughts. If I do not think of you, you will not arise.
The Buddha was walking on the road and heard this. He told the monks:
Record it!
This is a verse of KÄÅ›yapa Buddha that has been passed down in the secular world.
The Buddha said:
People give rise to sorrow from desire, and from sorrow, fear arises.
Without desire, there is no sorrow, and without sorrow, there is no fear.
The Buddha said:

Practicing the Way is like a person fighting a battle with ten thousand people. Wearing armor, holding weapons, leaving home to fight, if one's mind is timid and cowardly, one will retreat. Some turn back halfway, some die in battle, while some achieve great victory and are promoted to high positions in the country.

If a person can firmly hold their mind, diligently and resolutely practice, and not be confused by the words of the vulgar and foolish, then they will surely attain the Way in order to extinguish all evil.
There was a monk who recited the sutra at night with great sorrow, feeling regret and doubt, wanting to give rise to thoughts of returning.
The Buddha called the monk and asked him:
What did you do when you were at home?
He replied:
I always played the zither.
The Buddha said:
What if the strings are too loose?
He said:
It does not sound.
What if the strings are too tight?
He said:
The sound is cut off.
What if the strings are neither too loose nor too tight?
All the notes are sorrowful.
The Buddha told the monk:
Practicing the Way is also like this. If one holds the mind in balance, one can attain the Way.
The Buddha said:
When a person practices the Way, it is like gradually deepening the process of forging iron, discarding impurities, and the resulting vessel will surely be excellent.
Cultivating the Way is gradual, removing mental defilements, and diligently progressing towards the Way.
If one is violent, the body becomes tired, and if the body is tired, the mind becomes troubled. If the mind is troubled, practice retreats, and if practice retreats, one cultivates offenses.
The Buddha said:
It is suffering to practice the Way, and it is also suffering not to practice the Way.
From the time a person is born until old age, from old age until sickness, and from sickness until death, the suffering is immeasurable.
The mind is troubled and accumulates offenses, and birth and death are unceasing. The suffering is difficult to describe.
The Buddha said:
It is difficult for a person to leave the three evil paths and become a human.
Having already become a human, it is difficult to be a man after leaving the state of a woman;
Having already become a man, it is difficult for the six faculties to be complete;
Having already had the six faculties, it is difficult to be born in a central country;
Having already lived in a central country, it is difficult to encounter the Buddha's teachings;
Having already encountered the Buddha's teachings, it is difficult to encounter a ruler who has the Way, and it is difficult to be born in a bodhisattva's family;
Having already been born in a bodhisattva's family, it is difficult for the mind to have faith in the Three Jewels and encounter the Buddha's world.
The Buddha asked the monks:
How long is a person's life?
They replied:
It lasts for several days.
The Buddha said:
You are not yet able to practice the Way.
He then asked another monk:
How long is a person's life?
The monk replied:
It lasts for a meal.
The Buddha said:
You are not yet able to practice the Way.
He then asked another monk:
How long is a person's life?
The monk replied:
It lasts for the time of a breath.
The Buddha said:
Excellent!
You can be said to be practicing the Way.
The Buddha said:
If a disciple leaves me several thousand miles away, but keeps my precepts in mind, he will surely attain the Way.
If he is on my left side, but his mind is on evil, he will never attain the Way.
If he is far away but practices, what benefit is there in being close but not practicing?
The Buddha said:
Practicing the Way is like eating honey, the middle and edges are all sweet.
My sutras are also like this, their meaning is all delightful, and the practitioner attains the Way.
The Buddha said:
Practicing the Way can uproot desires, like plucking a string of pearls, plucking them one by one, there will eventually be an end.
When evil is exhausted, one attains the Way.
The Buddha said:
Monks practicing the Way should be like an ox pulling a cart through deep mud. Exhausted, it does not dare to look left or right, but wants to get out of the mud to rest.
Monks view desires as worse than that mud, with a sincere mind contemplating the Way, they can escape suffering.
